Comment: I like this puzzle a bunch. When I did the puzzle, I didn't know the math that makes it very easy and even now, I still don't understand the math that makes it easy. I chose to do a simulation. My first simulation was far too slow to pass all the test cases, so I had to do a tiny bit of optimization. As far as optimization goes, it was very easy to optimize my solution.

The reason I share all this is because I believe some reviewers might argue for this puzzle to be medium instead of easy. I'm okay with the easy tag. The simulation approach is probably toward the hard end of easy, but it is a lot easier than many medium level puzzles on CG.

My bet is that after this puzzle goes live, there will be discussion in the forum about the math. That's fine. It will still be a great little puzzle to practice building a simulation of a relatively small and reasonably simple system.

It appears you changed the format of your input, putting all the reflectivity numbers on a single line instead of listed on separate lines. Why the change?

You will need to update your Input section if this is indeed what you want.

I *assume* that a mirror in this puzzle has the same reflectivity on both sides, correct? (But, in real life I only know mirrors with high reflectivity at one side, and no reflectivity at the back side, so this assumption is not necessarily the most logical interpretation). If my assumption is correct, please add it explicitly to the statement, since it is information needed to solve the puzzle.

Would you consider switching Test Case 4 and Validator 4? For those of us that don’t know the math and opt for simulation, I think it’s important that the validator be easier than the test case when possible. Because of the higher reflectivity in validator 4, it takes a lot longer for the light to dissipate than it did for test case 4. I’m OK with the timing out. I just want it to happen on the test case as compared to the validator.

No, it is not easy, it is medium at least.
But the problem is interesting, I like it.

BTW, I failed to make the math to receive that simple solution as you do.
